poem:
**The Lifeguard's Towel**

Pooled in sunlight, the hotel buzzes   
with splash and laughter. A girl, thirteen,   
stands still as red threads weave without warning.   
Beneath the waterline, whispers rise—   
the quietest kindness: terrycloth draped,   
a shawl of solace from the blue-eyed watchman,   
his silent gesture, more than heroics,   
turns tremble into quiet calm.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The kindness of strangers: when my period arrived, a lifeguard quietly put a towel around me It wasn’t my first period, but it was within the first year of getting my period. I was only 13 years old and, when you first start menstruating, you never know when your next period is going to arrive. I was away on holiday with my family, playing in the hotel pool with some new friends I’d just met.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
